title: WEATHER UPDATE (Nov 3rd): TYPHOON KALMAEGI CHANGES COURSE, INTENSIFIES TO DANGEROUS CATEGORY 14! According to the Nation
description: WEATHER UPDATE (Nov 3rd): TYPHOON KALMAEGI CHANGES COURSE, INTENSIFIES TO DANGEROUS CATEGORY 14! According to the National Center for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting (NCHMF), Typhoon KALMAEGI is accelerating towards the East Sea (Biển Đông). As of 7:00 AM on November 3rd, the typhoon's center was holding Force 11, gusting to 15, and has shifted its course to West-Southwest, moving quickly at 25km/h. Forecasts indicate the typhoon will continue to change direction towards West-Northwest, and around 7:00 AM on November 5th, it will enter the East Sea, officially becoming Typhoon No. 13. Most alarming: by 7:00 AM on November 6th, the typhoon is likely to intensify to a catastrophic Force 14, gusting to 17, situated about 430km East-Southeast of Gia Lai province's coastline. A Level 4 Disaster Risk Warning has been issued for the central East Sea (including the Trường Sa archipelago), signaling extreme danger at sea. Meanwhile, the Central region is enduring historic rainfall. The NCHMF reports that in the past 24 hours (ending 10:00 AM on November 3rd), record rainfall levels were recorded: Bà Nà (Da Nang) at 514.2mm and Hương Sơn (Hue City) at 502.8mm. The torrential rain persists, and over the next 3-6 hours, accumulated rainfall in Hue City and Da Nang City could still reach 60-100mm, with some areas exceeding 200mm. The soil moisture model indicates that many areas in Ha Tinh, Quang Tri, Hue, Da Nang, and Quang Ngai have reached or are near saturation (over 85%), which significantly raises the risk of flash floods, landslides, and ground subsidence. Areas facing extremely high risks include: Hòa Vang, Hải Vân, Sơn Trà (Da Nang City); steep terrain areas in Ha Tinh (Hương Khê, Kỳ Anh), Quang Tri (Đakrông, Hướng Phùng), Hue City (A Lưới, Lộc An), and Quang Ngai (Sơn Tây, Tây Trà Bồng). Authorities and residents in all listed high-risk communes/wards must increase monitoring and be prepared for immediate evacuation as directed by local authorities. #TyphoonKalmaegi #DaNangAlert #FloodWarning #SevereWeather #DaNang365 #DN365 #DaNang #ExpatsinDaNang #Vietnam #TravelVietnam #LifeinVietnam #ExploreVietnam CREDIT: Trung tâm DBKTTVQG

title: Flood Update - Hoi An Nov 3rd 2025 Flooded Again-Locals Forced to Evacuate Twice in Just a Few Days After days of cleanu
description: Flood Update - Hoi An Nov 3rd 2025 Flooded Again-Locals Forced to Evacuate Twice in Just a Few Days After days of cleanup, Hoi An residents are once again facing rising waters. As river levels in Da Nang surged back today (Nov 3rd), many low-lying neighborhoods in the ancient town have been submerged for the second time. People living along the Hoai River - on Bach Dang, Nguyen Thai Hoc, and Tran Phu streets - are struggling as floodwaters return. The An Hoi area and Hoi An Market are among the hardest hit, with some places over a meter deep. Locals are using boats to move belongings to higher ground once more. #HoiAnFlood #CentralVietnamFloods #HoiAnToday #DaNang #VietnamWeather #HoiAnAncientTown #FloodRelief #PrayForCentralVietnam #ExpatsInDaNang #VietnamNews #DaNang365

title: Still think Ba Na Hills is all about the Golden Bridge? Let us prove you wrong Beyond the famous hands-in-the-sky, this
description: Still think Ba Na Hills is all about the Golden Bridge? Let us prove you wrong Beyond the famous hands-in-the-sky, this mountaintop wonder hides dozens of magical corners that’ll make you feel like you’ve stepped into another world. Sunlight Square (Quảng trường Nhật Thực): Where light meets architecture. Under angel statues and a crystal glass dome, every twirl becomes a runway moment. The Dung Nham Castle: Rising from the cliffs with colossal stone faces and bold red towers, this castle feels straight out of a fantasy film, dramatic, mysterious, unforgettable. The Sun God Fountain (Thác Thần Mặt Trời): Golden horses galloping through sparkling streams of light — especially magical at sunset when the sky glows amber. Le Jardin d’Amour Flower Garden: A dreamscape of blooms where a giant sunflower goddess stands guard. Every corner is made for slow strolls, deep breaths, and endless photos. Pro tip: Visit in the late afternoon, when the mist starts to roll in and Ba Na turns golden, that’s when this mountaintop wonder truly comes alive.

title: Hi everyone, Seeing a lot of concern, so I wanted to share a measured perspective based on the data and my own experienc
description: Hi everyone, Seeing a lot of concern, so I wanted to share a measured perspective based on the data and my own experience. Data: Da Nang is about 330km from the strongest point of the typhoon's eye (which is passing near Quy Nhon), as you can see from the maps. Experience: I've lived through at least 5 Category 3-4 hurricanes (the Central American equivalent). Based on this, we should absolutely expect heavy rains, strong winds, and likely flooding. However, this is very different from the direct-hit, Category 5 damage I've also experienced. We are on the outer edge of the storm, not in the direct path of the eyewall. Please continue to be prepared, take all precautions, and check in on your neighbors. May everyone remain as safe as possible.

title: There has been a few mentions about using a WISE card in Vietnam. Be aware their ATM withdrawl fees are very high, also
description: There has been a few mentions about using a WISE card in Vietnam. Be aware their ATM withdrawl fees are very high, also in my case they never refunded any charges for failed ATM withdrawals which is also quite common. I reviewed my statements and they owe me over 300 USD, in charges they did not refund. I believe the charges increase according to frequency of withdrawals, it appears to me they were also adding these failed ATM attempts as frequency and therefore increasing charges on completed ATM withdrawals.

title: Typhoon Kalmaegi Update – November 6, 2025: Strong Winds and Rough Seas Across the East Sea As reported by the National
description: Typhoon Kalmaegi Update – November 6, 2025: Strong Winds and Rough Seas Across the East Sea As reported by the National Center for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting, the tropical convergence zone between 11°–14°N is linked to Typhoon No.13. At 7:00 a.m., the storm center was near 13.2°N – 112.3°E, showing strong intensity and a wide impact area across the East Sea. Over the next 24 hours, strong winds and high waves will persist. In the northern East Sea (including the Paracel Islands), northeast winds reach level 6–7, gusting 8–9, with waves 4–6 meters high. From southern Quang Tri to Khanh Hoa, including Ly Son and Cu Lao Cham, winds reach level 8–11, near the center 12–14, gusting 17, with waves up to 9 meters. Heavy rain and thunderstorms are hitting the central and southern East Sea, including the Spratly Islands and coastal waters from Quang Tri to Khanh Hoa. Inland areas such as Lam Dong, Ca Mau, and An Giang may see scattered showers, thunderstorms, and whirlwinds with gusts up to level 7. By November 7, east winds at levels 5–6, gusting 7–8, will dominate the northern East Sea, with waves 3–5 meters high. From southern Quang Tri to Dak Lak, winds will reach level 6, gusting 7–8, with rough seas. Marine disaster risk: Level 4 (very dangerous): Western-central East Sea & coastal areas from Quang Ngai to Dak Lak Level 3: From southern Quang Tri to Khanh Hoa Level 2: Northern East Sea & Tonkin Gulf Warning: Strong winds and waves threaten vessels, coastal infrastructure, and buildings. Residents in affected coastal zones should evacuate to safe shelters and follow official forecasts for Typhoon Kalmaegi’s latest updates. Below are images showing the devastation left by Typhoon No.13 in the Philippines — a reminder of its destructive force. #Typhoon #VietnamWeather #CentralVietnam #StormAlert #HeavyRain #StaySafe #DaNang365 #DN365 #DaNang #ExpatsinDaNang #Vietnam CREDIT: National Center for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting
